metadata.title: Practical exact algorithm for trembling-hand equilibrium refinements in games
metadata.author: Gabriele Farina, Nicola Gatti, Tuomas Sandholm
metadata.journal: Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems
metadata.abstract: Nash equilibrium strategies have the known weakness that they do not prescribe rational play in situations that are reached with zero probability according to the strategies themselves, for example, if players have made mistakes. Tremblinghand refinements—such as extensive-form perfect equilibria and quasi-perfect equilibria—remedy this problem in sound ways. Despite their appeal, they have not received attention in practice since no known algorithm for computing them scales beyond toy instances. In this paper, we design an exact polynomial-time algorithm for finding trembling-hand equilibria in zero-sum extensive-form games. It is several orders of magnitude faster than the best prior ones, numerically stable, and quickly solves game instances with tens of thousands of nodes in the game tree. It enables, for the first time, the use of trembling-hand refinements in practice.

highlights: Nash equilibrium (NE) [Nash, 1950] is the most seminal solution concept in game theory
We prove that there is a tight connection between a stable basis and a trembling linear program limit solution
We develop a practical algorithm for finding a limit solution in a trembling linear program → P ( )
Unlike the exact Nash equilibrium computation, additional pivoting steps are needed by the rational simplex to find a QPE or an EFPE, even after warm starting from a Nash equilibrium
We introduced trembling linear problems (TLPs), which are linear programs in which every entry can be subject to an independent perturbation expressed by a polynomial in > 0

trembling linear program provide a framework for analyzing and computing important Nash equilibrium refinements based on various forms of trembling-hand perfection in two-player zero-sum games, such as quasi-perfect equilibria (QPEs) and extensive-form perfect equilibria (EFPEs)
key_statements: Nash equilibrium (NE) [Nash, 1950] is the most seminal solution concept in game theory
In the case of imperfectinformation extensive-form games, one limitation is that some Nash equilibrium do not prescribe optimal play after the player or the opponent has made a mistake
In two-player zero-sum games, the problems of finding a QPE or an EFPE can be formulated as limit points of linear programs parameterized by the tremble magnitude
In the subsections we review key properties of the two main trembling-hand refinements, QPEs and EFPEs
We introduce the concept of basis stability for trembling linear program
We prove that there is a tight connection between a stable basis and a trembling linear program limit solution
We develop a practical algorithm for finding a limit solution in a trembling linear program → P ( )
Unlike the exact Nash equilibrium computation, additional pivoting steps are needed by the rational simplex to find a QPE or an EFPE, even after warm starting from a Nash equilibrium
We introduced trembling linear problems (TLPs), which are linear programs in which every entry can be subject to an independent perturbation expressed by a polynomial in > 0

trembling linear program provide a framework for analyzing and computing important Nash equilibrium refinements based on various forms of trembling-hand perfection in two-player zero-sum games, such as quasi-perfect equilibria (QPEs) and extensive-form perfect equilibria (EFPEs)
summary: Nash equilibrium (NE) [Nash, 1950] is the most seminal solution concept in game theory.

The two most famous trembling-hand solution concepts that refine NEs while guaranteeing sequential rationality are quasi-perfect equilibria (QPEs) [van Damme, 1984] and extensive-form perfect equilibria (EFPEs) [Selten, 1975].1 In a QPE, a player plays optimally at every information set taking into account possible future mistakes of her opponent but assuming that she will not make future mistakes.
In two-player zero-sum games, the problems of finding a QPE or an EFPE can be formulated as limit points of linear programs parameterized by the tremble magnitude.
Like Nash equilibrium, a QPE and EFPE can be computed in polynomial time in the size of the input game.
In a zero-sum extensive-form game with perfect recall, a limit point as ↓ 0 of solutions of the linear problem in Figure 1(a) is the strategy of player i ∈ {1, 2} in a QPE.
In a zero-sum extensive-form game with perfect recall, a limit point as ↓ 0 of solutions of the linear problem in Figure 1(b) is the strategy of player i ∈ {1, 2} in an EFPE.

The previous section shows that the problems of finding a QPE and that of finding an EFPE are similar: in both cases an LP with a parameter > 0 is given, and a limit point of a sequence of optimal solutions to the LP as ↓ 0 is sought.
Given a stable basis, one can find a TLP limit solution in polynomial time: Theorem 5.
If in the QPE formulation of Proposition 1, the LP constraint matrix A is constant, meaning that the optimality certificate b has polynomial entries, it is extremely easy to deal with.
Unlike the exact NE computation, additional pivoting steps are needed by the rational simplex to find a QPE or an EFPE, even after warm starting from a Nash equilibrium.

TLPs provide a framework for analyzing and computing important Nash equilibrium refinements based on various forms of trembling-hand perfection in two-player zero-sum games, such as quasi-perfect equilibria (QPEs) and extensive-form perfect equilibria (EFPEs).

We designed an exact polynomial-time algorithm for finding a limit solution to a TLP that, when applied to finding a QPE or EFPE, outperforms the speed of prior algorithms by several orders of magnitude.
Our algorithm quickly solves games with tens of thousands of nodes, enabling—for the first time—the use of trembling-hand refinements in practice.
headline: The solution concepts we study in this paper—QPEs and EFPEs—guarantee sequential rationality and are a standard solution to this problem.2 1.1
